EmuFog [91] ✓
Fogbed [34] ✓
xFogSim is lightweight, configurable, scalable and introduces the concept of fog federation for resource sharing among fog locations.
iFogSim allows users to measure, in a repeatable manner, the impact of resource management techniques in terms of latency, network congestion, energy consumption, and cost.
EnOSlib is a library which brings reusable building blocks for configuring the infrastructure, provisioning software on remote hosts as well as organizing the experimental workflow.
iFogSim [63] ✓
Fed4Edge uses RDF Stream Processing (RSP) engines as autonomous processing agents.
KubeEdge key features are: core infrastructure support for networking; application deployment; and metadata synchronization between Cloud and Edge.
Fed4FIRE+ [41] is a project offering the largest federation worldwide of Next Generation Internet (NGI) testbeds.
Fed4FIRE aims to provide open, accessible and reliable experimental infrastructures supporting a wide variety of research, such as 5G, IoT, Cloud Computing, Wired and Wireless Computer Networking.
KubeEdge [159] ✓ Deploy complex high level applications to the Edge.

FogNetSim++ [115] focuses on simulating large Fog networks and differs from others mainly by providing features that allow users to incorporate customized mobility models, scheduling algorithms, and manage handover mechanisms.
CLONE [86] is a collaborative learning setting on the Edge built on top of the Federated Learning algorithm and long short-term memory networks.
ElasticSim [26] is a workflow simulator that extends CloudSim.
FogExplorer allows users to choose good application designs during its design phase.
Fogbed [34] allows resource provisioning emulation in Fog environments.
EmuFog [91] focuses on the design of Fog Computing infrastructures and the emulation of real applications and workloads.

ORBIT [105] (Open-Access Research Testbed for Next-Generation Wireless Networks) is based on a 20x20 twodimensional grid of programmable radio nodes which can be interconnected into different topologies.
XFogSim [90] ✓ Simulate federated fog computing environments.
XFogSim [90] extends FogNetSim++ to simulate federated fog computing environments.
FogTorch [25] aims to support the deployment of IoT applications in Fog infrastructures considering software, hardware and QoS requirements.
KubeEdge [159] builds on top of Kubernetes to extend Cloud capabilities to the Edge and allows containerized application orchestration and device management to hosts at the Edge.
ElasticSim [26] ✓ Simulate autoscaling algorithms.
FogNetSim [115] ✓ Simulate distributed fog computing environments.
RADICAL-DREAMER allows users to evaluate deployment configurations, performance trade-offs, and workload placement strategies for Edge-to-Cloud applications [87].
FogExplorer [65] ✓ Simulate QoS and cost evaluation of fog-based IoT applications.
FogExplorer [65] provides modeling and simulation to estimate QoS and cost evaluation of Fog-based IoT applications.
EdgeCloudSim [137] focuses on Edge Computing scenarios and allows one to conduct experiments considering computational and networking resources.

SmartSantander [126] is a large scale testbed composed of around 2000 IEEE 802.15.4 devices deployed in a 3-tiered architecture (IoT node, repeaters, and gateway node) deployment in the Spanish city of Santander.
RADICAL-DREAMER [116] provides the concepts of Task and Workload to model the characteristics of an application according to heterogeneous tasks.
In CLONE, the learning tasks are solved by a group of distributed Edge nodes.
In EmuFog, users can: design the network topology; embed Fog nodes in the topology; and run Docker-based applications on those nodes connected by an emulated network.

Lastly, iFogSim [63] focuses on resource management techniques in IoT, Edge and Fog computing environments.

Edge Cluster Stream Processing (ECStream) allows time-constrained data-intensive applications to be entirely deployed and executed at the Edge and it is based on a task parallelism model where atomic tasks are offloaded to peer Edge devices, rather than the full workflow.

Furthermore, we discuss the recent efforts and initiatives merging large scale testbeds for enabling more realistic setups for Edge-to-Cloud experiments, such as: Grid'5000 and FIT IoT-Lab; Chameleon and CHI@Edge; and the Fed4FIRE project.

It discusses techniques to support Deep Learning models at the Edge, for example: (1) systems and toolkits: OpenEI, a framework for Edge Intelligence; AWS IoT Greengrass, for ML Inference; Azure IoT Edge; and Cloud IoT Edge; and (2) open source Deep Learning packages: Tensor-Flow, Caffe2, PyTorch, MXNet, and some distributed Deep Learning models over Cloud and Edge such as DDNN and Neurosurgeon.

Novel approaches should also leverage the transfer of knowledge to/from different domains (e.g., useful when data for training is scarce) and also take advantage of the parallelism and scalability provided by state-of-the-art distributed stream processing systems (e.g., Flink, Spark, etc.) combined with Machine Learning paradigms [52] in order to speed up the training and inference time.
